awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Antiferromagnetic Spin-Flop Transitions in Heusler-Piezoelectric Systems Induced via Voltage
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing new materials with unique magnetic and electronic properties is at the forefront of materials science and nanotechnology. In this project, materials with a unique combination of magnetic, electronic, and strain properties are studied to advance future applications in ultrahigh-frequency (Terahertz) transistors and wireless communications, which are necessary to meet the ever increasing size of data sets and the speed of data transmission. The midshipmen (undergraduates at the Naval Academy) involved in this project will participate in educational outreach of underrepresented groups in the sciences - including young women in the local areas. This project will also serve as a training ground for midshipmen and undergraduates in magnetic nanostructures and information technology. 

Multiferroic materials have been proposed for an array of applications due to their binary or ternary co-existing magnetic spin, electric dipole, and ferroelastic properties. These multiferroic properties have been found in single phase compounds, however, they are rare and will have operating limitations in future devices, including low operational temperatures where the multiferroic properties co-exist. Compared to single-compound multiferroics, the arena is far larger for artificial multiferroics containing composites of dissimilar materials. This project focuses on coupling versatile magnetoelastic Heusler compounds strain-coupled to a piezoelectric substrate (e.g. PMN-PT) to mimic single-phase antiferromagnetic (AFM) multiferroic properties for THz AFM spintronics. Heterostructures will be grown using molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) and sputtering. Various methods including polarized beam reflectometry, synchrotron X-ray diffraction, and X-ray magnetic circular dichroism will be employed to fully investigate the voltage control of the crystallographic and magnetic structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
• Topological materials that are also magnetic could provide important foundations for future electronic devices, in particular for quantum electronics. Several novel topological magnetic materials were synthesized for the first time. These new materials were characterized with respect to their unique properties, especially those related to spintronic applications. These include NiBi2Te4, 1T-FeTe2 and FeGe.
  • Materials that are only a few atoms thick provide for totally brand-new physics. A new 2D material only a few atomic layers thick, composed of Cr2Te3, was found to a have unique Hall voltage that changed sign as its temperature changed. This was found to be caused by an esoteric bit of physics identified as the Berry phase curvature.
  • Magnetic materials with helical spin configurations – think of a DNA helix composed of atoms containing magnetic arrows that rotate in a circle – could be poised to be the foundation for magnetic bubble-like memories referred to as skyrmions. Precise magnetic and conductivity measurement on Fe3Ga4 and FeGe show that these materials could be the basis for such memories.
  • It was discovered that a well-used magnetic insulator, Y3Fe5O12 or simply YIG, when grown by liquid phase epitaxy had negligible magnetic losses at low temperatures. This could be useful for low-temperature experiments/applications that require low magnetic losses, perhaps for quantum computer applications which require very low temperatures.
  • Innovative applications could become possible by the marriage of antiferromagnetic (AFM) spintronics and superconductivity (SC). It was found that V3Ga can exist in both AFM and SC states at the same temperature. This was found in V3Ga films that were synthesizes by molecular beam epitaxy.
  • An undergraduate, Adrican Fedorko, performed the majority of the work on the Fe3Ga4 publication. A PhD student, Nirjhar Bhattacharjee, completed his thesis work while generating three TI/magnetic papers. A PhD student, Alexandrea Will-Cole, completed her thesis work while generating three papers.
  • 16 papers were published in archival journals, including: Nat Commun., Adv. Mater., Phys. Rev. Mater., ACS, J. Alloys Comp., Appl. Phys. Lett. and Phys. Rev. B. One other paper has been submitted.
